data.title: linux argument startup fix
data.body:
You shouldn't put the the script's arguments in a variable without keeping them as a list because the arguments were merged and then splitted with whitespace. This results in a total mashup of tabs. 

See Issue https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/17852

1. Install Visual Studio Code via AUR
2. open terminal

4. vscode opens and creates the tabs "a" "b" and "c.txt"

data.title: TS syntax highlighting broken for (1 / 1) * (1 / (1 + 1))
data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.7.2 - OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12 ### Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open a new .ts file, all default settings 2. Type `console.log((1 / 1) * (1 / (1 + 1)));` ### Expected output: Syntax highlighting should resemble the output when replacing `(1 + 1)` with `2`: ### Actual output: Syntax highlighting breaks and highlights all following code in red and orange:

data.title: Request: Improve user experience of settings overridding (User Settings)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 14

I'm new to VS Code, and what situation I have. One day I redefined the setting **extensions.autoUpdate** by **true** value (**extensions.autoUpdate = true**). I forgot about after some time. Soon I looked for the current state of extensions.autoUpdate setting. So, what I've done - I went to Workspace Settings and what I see:
![autoupdate1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5967447/21497348/102293d0-cc2d-11e6-8a79-7272582fca09.png)

**extensions.autoUpdate = false**

Ok. But what we see in the User Settings:

![autoupdate2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5967447/21497357/1797d5f8-cc2d-11e6-8270-c71c8b80b8fd.png)

At the left pane **extensions.autoUpdate = false** again, but then we look to the right pane and there is **extensions.autoUpdate = true**.

**Request**: there should be the way to display current settings value at the **left pane** in the case when the option is overwritten.

Thank you!

data.title: Add syntax highlighting for JS/TS template string interpolation (Monokai built-in theme)

data.title: [c++] syntax highlighting stops at middle of a file on ruby.h
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Home 14393.576

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open `include\ruby\ruby.h` of ruby 2.4.0 source code. Link to the archive is [Here](https://cache.ruby-lang.org/pub/ruby/2.4/ruby-2.4.0.tar.gz).
2. Scroll to line 1810.
3. Highlighting stops at line 1810. Please see this screenshot.
![screenshot](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22886576/21488970/f958e9c8-cc28-11e6-9027-3dde375f07e2.gif)

Note:
- Visual Studio 2015 community shows highlighting correctly.
- This issue might be same to #16605.

data.title: Keeps Selecting Text when Navigating Document with Keys
data.body: Edit: Nevermind the issue was an error on my end

data.title: Suggestion ranking should honour order
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: win10x64

Case: 
```js
var path = require('path');
```
when I type "path." I get
![](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/105338698/ShareX/2016-12/Code_2016-12-27_00-46-52.png)
next I want to select "parse" method so I hit "p" and get
![](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/105338698/ShareX/2016-12/Code_2016-12-27_00-47-50.png)

Notice that the list is scrolled to the bottom, the Intellisense stuff remains on the top.

Problem:
``path`` is definitely typed and Intellisense serves all it's properties and methods. Intellisense' stuff is already on the top and it is shown immediately after I hit ".". It's quite unlikely I'll ever need access anything else. So why would VSCode suggest otherwise? It would be ok if this auto-generated stuff would stay on the bottom of the list, just like it does, but why is it preferred?

I tried
```
"editor.snippetSuggestions"
"editor.quickSuggestions"
"editor.quickSuggestionsDelay"
"editor.suggestOnTriggerCharacters"
"editor.wordBasedSuggestions"
```
but nothing seems to have an effect in this regard.

thank you.

data.title: HTML Script Tag Scope Bug
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

The initial `<` bracket in the opening `<script>` tag _does not_ have the proper scope attached to it, neither does the `>` bracket in the closing `</script>` tag.

Also, it would be nice to have _specific_ scopes to target javascript attributes in html tags, ie: `onclick`, as well as the `style` attribute in html tags. Because those attributes are deal with to presentation and behavior (not just DOM markup), it would be nice to have the _possibility_ to customize them in themes.

Below is a screenshot showing the issue.

![scopes](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1389303/21487026/3c435a10-cb85-11e6-8b11-5e18716b868e.png)

data.title: Create Scope For `activeGuide` In Custom Themes

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

I read through the [VSCode theme scopes](https://code.visualstudio.com/Docs/customization/themes#_creating-a-custom-theme). I'd like a way to target the active guide, ie:

```
<key>guide</key>
<string>#3A3A39</string>
<key>activeGuide</key>
<string>#5D5D5D</string>
```
Additionally, a setting to choose `line`, `dotted`, or `dashed` for the guide style would be welcomed... perhaps a string could be passed to the `"editor.renderIndentGuides"` property instead of a boolean.

data.title: Check window.autoDetectHighContrast on window load
data.body:
Complete the fix of #17279. Previous PR #17394 only affected the case when switching Windows theme with VSCode.

This PR ensures VSCode won't start in High Contrast theme if `windows.autoDetectHighContrast` is `false`.

data.title: [Bug] lodash types weird intellisense output
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: OSX Sierra

This is the output of VSCode with the `@types/lodash` package:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9698639/21484318/855756b0-cb5e-11e6-8b78-bb8e38d91ea0.png)

I expected to see at least `map` intellisense, and most likely `flatMap` and a few others.

tsconfig file:

```ts
{
  "compilerOptions": {
    "target": "es5",
    "module": "commonjs",
    "moduleResolution": "node",
    "emitDecoratorMetadata": true,
    "experimentalDecorators": true,
    "allowSyntheticDefaultImports": true,
    "sourceMap": true,
    "noEmitHelpers": true,
    "strictNullChecks": false,
    "baseUrl": "./src",
    "paths": {},
    "lib": [
      "dom",
      "es6"
    ],
    "types": [
      "hammerjs",
      "jasmine",
      "node",
      "selenium-webdriver",
      "source-map",
      "uglify-js",
      "webpack",
      "lodash"
    ]
  },
  "exclude": [
    "node_modules",
    "dist"
  ],
  "awesomeTypescriptLoaderOptions": {
    "forkChecker": true,
    "useWebpackText": true
  },
  "compileOnSave": false,
  "buildOnSave": false,
  "atom": { "rewriteTsconfig": false }
}
```

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install with `npm i -D lodash @types/lodash`.
2. Create ts file and try to import lodash map function, it will not even show `map`, nor `flatMap` nor others.

data.title: Unable to override quit shortcut on Mac
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.8.1 (ee428b0eead68bf0fb99ab5fdc4439be227b6281, 2016-12-19T14:42:49.304Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.1.0
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|beautify|HookyQR|0.6.2|
|html-snippets|abusaidm|0.0.18|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.2|
|vscode-JS-CSS-HTML-formatter|lonefy|0.2.2|
|JavaScriptSnippets|xabikos|1.2.0|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. configured `keybindings.json` and added `{ "key": "cmd+q", "command": "-workbench.action.quit" }`, even tried keeping the `command` blank. But it always quits when `cmd+q` is pressed.

I would like to avoid accidental quit hence trying to remove all quit shortcuts.

data.title: If rename file, a zero-length file is created at old name

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1 (1.8.1)
- OS Version: OS X 10.10.5

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Click on file in Explorer pane to select the file
2. Press return to go into rename mode
3. Type in a new name
4. Press RETURN to save new name

Results:
1. File will be properly renamed
2. After a few moments, a new empty file will be created at the old file location.

Comments:
- Problem DOES occur if move file into directory by dragging in the Explorer pane
- Problem does NOT occur if rename using native command line
- As this problem is so obvious, and I can find no reports of it, I suspect an environmental issue, specifically a VSCode extension. I currently have the following installed:
  - Complete JSDoc Tags 0.0.2
  - Document This 0.3.5
  - ESLint 1.2.2
  - Regex Previewer 0.0.7
  - TODO Parser 1.8.3
  - TSLint 0.7.1

Happy to provide further information or do additional tests.

data.title: Please add options for sorting and choosing which file type to view in the Explorer panel
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

I'm working on an big project. I view my current folder by the Explorer panel in the left. My current folder have a lot of file of many type. And I only want to show files of a specific type. Please add some option for viewing and sorting file!

data.title: Build-in Terminal and tooltips don't use subpixel rendering
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Linux

The build-in Terminal and the code tooltips are rendered with only grayscale anti-aliasing.
The code itself and the rest of the GUI is rendered with subpixel anti-aliasing.

So please also enable subpixel rendering for the tooltips and the terminal.

Thanks.

data.title: Please do NOT autocomplete the TypeScript module name when ".." is typed.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Windows 10.0.10586

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a project that references at least one module with name(s) containing the character ., like `zone.js`, in package.json.
2. Run `npm install`.
3. Create a TypeScript file.
4. Type `import {} from ".."` in the created file.
5. While I was trying to reference a module from the parent folder of the one the created file is within, what is automatically completed, instead, is something like `import {} from "zone.js"`.
